summary: This document is a collection of email correspondence from August-September 2019, primarily concerning complaints about conditions for a client (Mr. Tartaglione) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The emails are between defense attorney Bruce Barket, Assistant U.S. Attorneys, and others. The document also includes a header for a Google Alert email on 'ethics' from September 10, 2019, which contains news summaries, including one mentioning MIT's ties to Jeffrey Epstein. This document contains email correspondence primarily concerning conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes emails between defense attorney Bruce Barket, prosecutors, and prison officials discussing inmate treatment, scheduling calls, and updates on the Epstein suicide investigation. This document contains email correspondence primarily between attorneys and government officials regarding legal matters for a client named 'Nick Tartaglione' at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It includes scheduling discussions, requests for client movement, and arrangements for a private investigator visit. A forwarded Washington Post article about the Affordable Care Act is also included. This document is a compilation of news articles from a publication (likely The Washington Post's 'Daily 202'). The primary focus relevant to the Epstein case is on the political fallout from the unsealing of the 2008 plea deal, including calls for Labor Secretary Alex Acosta's resignation, Attorney General William Barr's recusal decision, and details about Jeffrey Epstein's network and his past relationship with Donald Trump. This document is an email newsletter from The Washington Post titled 'The Daily 202' dated July 10, 2019. It covers various news topics including Saudi Arabia's lobbying efforts in the U.S., a trial involving a Saudi princess, tech industry news, and political commentary. The document appears to be part of a larger collection of Epstein-related materials, though its direct connection to the Epstein case is not evident from this excerpt. This is an email chain from August 30, 2019, discussing the allocation of Temporary Duty (TDY) costs for staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The discussion centers on whether these costs, related to implementing new procedures and policies following an incident (implicitly the Jeffrey Epstein incident), should be covered by a special project fund, similar to how costs for an earlier incident at MDC Brooklyn were handled. The response indicates that while some travel for an after-action team was covered, general TDY costs due to staff shortages were not, as such shortages are a nationwide issue to be absorbed locally. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails and a Google Alert regarding BOP news. Key content includes an email about not being authorized to charge TDY expenses related to 'Epstein Death' to a national project, a forwarded email about attorney Martin Weinberg having difficulty meeting with client Jeffrey Epstein, and a chronological log noting a staff error in using the wrong watch log for Epstein. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails and attached logs regarding the suicide watch of Jeffrey Epstein on July 23-24, 2019, and subsequent discussions about funding for Temporary Duty (TDY) staff costs related to the incident at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It reveals administrative confusion over logs and significant expenses incurred. This document contains a series of internal Bureau of Prisons emails from 2019 discussing staffing issues at MCC Chicago, a medical emergency for inmate Michael Elansky, and multiple messages regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's status, including his removal from suicide watch/psych observation prior to his death. The emails reveal concerns about facility procedures following Epstein's suicide. This document contains email correspondence and a detailed timeline related to Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes a minute-by-minute log of the incident, notifications to authorities, and subsequent email exchanges regarding staff interviews and inmate conditions. This document contains email correspondence and attachments related to legal visits and conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a complaint from attorney Bruce Barket about poor conditions for his client and a separate email chain regarding obtaining visitation approval for a private investigator to visit a different inmate at the MCC. This document contains email chains from July and November 2019. The July emails discuss difficulties attorney Martin Weinberg faced in meeting his client Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after Epstein's arrest. The November emails involve Judge Valerie Caproni and a Supervisory Staff Attorney discussing an upcoming meeting and mentioning the Epstein suicide investigation. This document contains email correspondence from November 2019 between a federal judge and a Bureau of Prisons attorney regarding a new warden and an upcoming meeting. It also includes forwarded Google Alerts about the Bureau of Prisons from July 2019 and January 2020, which mention Jeffrey Epstein's suicide attempt and investigation. This document is a collection of email correspondence and attachments from within the U.S. Bureau of Prisons (BOP) concerning Jeffrey Epstein's detention, suicide attempt, and death. It includes internal communications about media inquiries, attorney access, and a detailed timeline of the events surrounding Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019. This document contains email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons system regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's medical care and administrative matters while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes discussions about his CPAP machine, medication, and an extension cord memo, as well as a Google Alert about his death. This document contains email correspondence and attachments from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. It includes a memo about an extension cord for his CPAP machine, emails about releasing his medical records post-mortem, and a detailed timeline of the events surrounding his suicide on August 10, 2019. This document is a collection of email correspondence and attachments from August 2019 concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It includes a letter from the MCC Warden to Judge Berman confirming investigations into the July 23 incident, a media inquiry about prison conditions, a detailed timeline of Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, and a Google Alert email about the removal of a prisons director following Epstein's death. This document is a Google Alerts email digest from November 25, 2019, containing news headlines on prison-related topics. It includes a brief mention of an opinion piece titled 'Jeffrey Epstein's Death Shows the Need for Prison Reform' from The New York Times. The bulk of the document is a forwarded email from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' newsletter dated August 14, 2019, discussing economic uncertainty, trade wars, and political news, including a mention of former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich's potential commutation. This document appears to be a compilation of news articles from August 2019, covering various political and international stories. A significant portion focuses on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in federal custody, including the reassignment of prison staff, investigations into the circumstances, and the resulting political and legal fallout, including scrutiny of Prince Andrew and legal battles involving Alan Dershowitz. This document is a forwarded email newsletter from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' dated August 14, 2019. It contains aggregated news summaries on various topics including ICE raids in Mississippi, immigration policy, gun control debates, and media controversies. It appears to be part of a collection of documents related to the Epstein case, though its direct connection is not evident from this excerpt. This document contains two parts: 1) A forwarded email chain from July 19, 2019, between a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the CLC and defense attorney Bruce Barket regarding the conditions of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. 2) A preceding email newsletter from The Washington Post dated August 14, 2019, covering various political and economic news, including a section on the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the reassignment of prison staff. This document contains email correspondence from July 2019 regarding defense attorney Bruce Barket's complaints about severe difficulties in accessing his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It also includes an attached 'Suicide Timeline' document detailing the events surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC on August 10, 2019. This document contains a detailed timeline of events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, followed by a critical memorandum from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Reentry Services Division. The memo provides feedback on the institution's response to a psychological reconstruction of the suicide, highlighting numerous procedural failures, lack of documentation, and institutional bias. This document contains email correspondence, primarily Google Alerts summaries and internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails, discussing news coverage and internal logistics following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The Google Alerts show media coverage of Epstein's suicide, BOP leadership changes, and related prison news. Internal BOP emails discuss funding for Temporary Duty (TDY) staff sent to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York after the incident. This document is a collection of email chains from Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff discussing logistical and financial issues related to the Jeffrey Epstein incident at MCC New York, including TDY costs, attorney access, and a Google Alert about BOP news. It reveals internal BOP communications about budget constraints and operational challenges following Epstein's death. This document is a collection of email chains from late 2019 concerning the conditions of confinement and legal representation of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails involve discussions between defense attorneys, MCC staff, and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding visitation issues, cell conditions, discovery access, and a suicide attempt. The emails also reference a check for any investigation into Tartaglione related to Jeffrey Epstein, which was confirmed as non-existent. This document contains email correspondence primarily concerning the detention conditions and legal access issues of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a forwarded email chain discussing a separate case (USA v. Jeffrey Epstein) at the end. The main thread details complaints from defense attorney Bruce Barket about poor conditions, visitation delays, and lack of access to legal materials for his client Tartaglione, with responses from prison staff and a prosecutor. This document contains a court order scheduling a hearing regarding the dismissal of charges against Jeffrey Epstein after his death, and email chains discussing attorney access for Epstein and another inmate (Nicholas Tartaglione) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The emails reveal concerns about detention conditions and attorney-client meeting difficulties. This document is a chain of email correspondence from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), with other parties copied. The emails detail persistent complaints about the harsh conditions of confinement and significant access issues for the legal team of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione, who is facing the death penalty and is held in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). The complaints include excessive delays for attorney visits, loss of legal materials and discovery, inadequate access to books, and deplorable cell conditions including water leaks and a dead rodent. This document contains several email threads from Bureau of Prisons (BOP) accounts, primarily from 2019. Key content includes an email regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch status, a forwarded news article about Attorney General William Barr's visit to a prison, a Google Alert email about BOP news including Epstein's death, and an email distributing an updated timeline document for Epstein. The emails show internal BOP communication and monitoring of media coverage related to Epstein and the BOP. This document contains a detailed timeline of events leading to Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) memos reviewing the psychological reconstruction of the suicide, highlighting institutional failures, and email correspondence regarding OIG interviews and the official closure of Epstein's criminal case. This document is a forwarded email chain from July 2019 concerning inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. Defense attorney Bruce Barket complains to prison officials and federal prosecutors about deplorable conditions, lack of access to legal materials, and systemic delays in attorney-client visits, hampering Tartaglione's defense in a death penalty case. This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 concerning inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions and legal access at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints about leaks, pests, lack of discovery materials, and excessive delays in attorney visits, forwarded to various MCC staff. It also contains metadata for a separate, later email regarding a psychological observation of Jeffrey Epstein. This document is an email from an Associate Warden at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, forwarding a PDF attachment titled 'Epstein Psych Observation 7-24-30-2019.pdf'. The email and its attachment pertain to Jeffrey Epstein's psychological observation and suicide watch logs from July 24-30, 2019, just prior to his death. The document includes metadata about the email's creation, delivery, and subsequent legal tagging. This document is an email with an attached timeline detailing the events surrounding the death of Jeffrey Epstein in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes a minute-by-minute log of the suicide watch observation, the medical emergency response, and notifications to various officials and agencies. This document contains email correspondence and a BOP memorandum related to Jeffrey Epstein's death and subsequent investigations. It includes a detailed suicide timeline from August 9-10, 2019, a forwarded memorandum with feedback on the institution's psychological reconstruction response, and email exchanges regarding legal meetings and conditions at MCC New York. This document contains email correspondence primarily concerning conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and attorney access issues. It includes complaints from attorney Bruce Barket about his client Nicholas Tartaglione's treatment and staffing problems, as well as internal emails about attorney Martin Weinberg's access to Jeffrey Epstein shortly after his arrest. A later email forwards a request for Epstein's autopsy documents. This document contains email correspondence from 2019 regarding legal and administrative issues for two federal inmates: Jeffrey Epstein and Nicholas Tartaglione. It includes concerns about Epstein's attorney access before his presentment, complaints about Epstein's conditions in the SHU, and requests related to Tartaglione's trial preparation. The emails are between attorneys, prison staff, and U.S. Attorney's Office personnel. This document is a collection of email correspondence and forwarded news articles from within the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) system. It includes a forwarded news article about the ousting of the federal prisons chief following Jeffrey Epstein's suicide, a newsletter of noteworthy news articles (including one about Epstein victims in Paris), and an email chain regarding a request by defense counsel to view the cell of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. The emails show coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office and BOP staff regarding the site visit request. This document is a collection of email correspondence primarily concerning legal and detention issues for two federal inmates: Jeffrey Epstein and Nicholas Tartaglione. It includes communications between defense attorneys, prison officials, and U.S. Attorney's Office staff regarding attorney-client meeting difficulties, conditions of confinement, and case preparation. This document is a forwarded email chain from July 2019 concerning the detention conditions and legal access issues of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. Defense attorney Bruce Barket details severe problems including leaks, rodents, lack of reading material and discovery, and systemic delays in attorney visits. The email is forwarded to a prison psychologist requesting a mental health evaluation for Tartaglione, who is facing the death penalty. This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) concerning the detention conditions and legal access difficulties of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. Barket details systemic problems including long delays for attorney visits, poor cell conditions (leaks, pests, lighting issues), loss of legal materials, and restrictive punishment. The MCC staff attorney responds with efforts to address some complaints. This document contains email correspondence regarding the conditions of confinement for inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, including attorney complaints about visitation delays and property access. It also includes a Bureau of Prisons clinical encounter report detailing the emergency medical response and resuscitation efforts for Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, after he was found unresponsive in his cell.

events.title: Books swapped for Tartaglione
events.description: An individual (name redacted) personally swapped out books for inmate Mr. Tartaglione at MCC.

events.title: Email complaint about MCC conditions
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket sends an email detailing ongoing problems for his client Mr. Tartaglione at MCC, including lack of book swaps, missing radio batteries, and intimidating comments from guards.

events.title: Scheduled call on MCC conditions
events.description: Legal team (Bruce Barket, AUSAs, others) schedule a conference call for the afternoon to discuss the complaints about conditions at MCC.

events.title: Google Alert on ethics
events.description: A Google Alert email is generated with news summaries on various ethics topics, including a mention of MIT's financial ties to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Tartaglione Book Swap
events.description: Mr. Tartaglione last had his books swapped out, an action he performed himself due to lack of staff assistance.

events.title: Call to Discuss MCC Conditions
events.description: Scheduled call between defense attorney Bruce Barket, prosecutors, and others to discuss ongoing problems at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Incident
events.description: The suicide of Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC, which triggered an outside investigation by the FBI, OIG, and USAO.

events.title: OIG Interview Requests
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General requests to interview MCC staff members regarding the incident involving Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: CJAB Meeting
events.description: Upcoming Criminal Justice Act Board meeting where the warden was to address attorney visiting study delays and the female unit at MCC.

events.title: Staff Attorney Transfer
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney CLC announces transfer to Deputy Regional Counsel for the Northeast Region in Philadelphia.

events.title: Email discussion on Tartaglione's MCC conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket emails AUSA Aida Leisenring to discuss conditions under which his client Nick Tartaglione would withdraw his request to be moved from MCC.

events.title: Scheduled meeting with Nick Tartaglione
events.description: Email exchange regarding a meeting with client Nick Tartaglione at MCC before his court hearing, mentioning a social visit with his mother had occurred.

events.title: Request for private investigator visit at MCC
events.description: Attorney Sarah Sacks requests permission for a private investigator appointed under CJA to visit a client at MCC, with Nicole McFarland providing the necessary forms.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta negotiated a plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein, allowing him to avoid federal prosecution on sex charges in exchange for pleading guilty to state charges.

events.title: New Federal Charges Against Epstein
events.description: Federal prosecutors in New York unsealed new sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein, leading to his arrest.

events.title: Political Fallout and Calls for Acosta's Resignation
events.description: Following the revelation of Epstein's new charges and details of the 2008 deal, prominent Democrats and some media called for Labor Secretary Alex Acosta to resign.

events.title: Trump-Epstein Party at Mar-a-Lago
events.description: A 'calendar girl' competition party was held at Mar-a-Lago where Donald Trump and Jeffrey Epstein were reportedly the only male guests.

events.title: Barr Announces Partial Recusal
events.description: Attorney General William Barr announced he would not recuse from the current Epstein prosecution but would recuse from any review of the 2008 plea deal due to a conflict.

events.title: Assault Incident in Paris
events.description: Egyptian workman Ashraf Eid was allegedly assaulted by the bodyguard of Princess Hassa bint Salman in Paris.

events.title: Congressional Tech Antitrust Hearing
events.description: Executives from Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google scheduled to testify before House Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust.

events.title: White House Social Media Summit
events.description: Trump summoned Republican lawmakers and social media figures to discuss alleged online bias against conservatives.

events.title: D.C. Council Action on Jack Evans
events.description: D.C. Council stripped Jack Evans of his committee chairmanship and voted to investigate him.

events.title: TDY Costs Discussion for MCC NY
events.description: Internal email discussion regarding funding for Temporary Duty staff at MCC New York to implement new procedures and policies following an incident.

events.title: Epstein Incident at MCC NY
events.description: Implied incident involving Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, leading to the need for new procedures, policies, and staff training/assistance.

events.title: MDC Brooklyn Incident
events.description: A prior incident at the Metropolitan Detention Center Brooklyn where TDY and other costs were covered by a special project fund.

events.title: Epstein's suicide
events.description: Referenced in an email as the event that occurred when "staff was caught sleeping and forging the log" at MCC New York.

events.title: Medication and Grooming Arrangements
events.description: Series of emails. One addresses allegations from Epstein's attorneys that he is not receiving cholesterol or back pain medication, with a pharmacist confirming an active Rx for Vascepa but no Rx for back pain. Another email discusses a brief delay for Epstein's attorney conference due to him getting a shower, haircut, and medical assessment.

events.title: Extension Cord Memo

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: A detailed timeline records Epstein being found unresponsive in his cell at 6:33 am. CPR is initiated, EMS is called, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital. He is pronounced dead at 7:36 am. Multiple agencies are notified, including the FBI, OIG, and the judge.

events.title: Post-Mortem Procedures

events.title: Epstein's last full day

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein found unresponsive in his cell at MCC at approximately 6:33 AM. CPR and medical efforts fail. He is pronounced dead at Beekman Hospital at 7:36 AM. The FBI and OIG are notified.

events.title: Trump Promotes Clinton-Epstein Conspiracy Theory

events.title: ICE Raids in Mississippi

keyFacts: Defense attorney Bruce Barket filed complaints in August 2019 about poor and intimidating conditions for his client, Mr. Tartaglione, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

Guards at MCC allegedly made intimidating comments to Tartaglione such as "You're threatening our lives" and "Give the big mouth his try," and refused to provide basic items like book swaps and radio batteries.
The email chain involves coordination between defense counsel (Barket) and prosecutors (AUSA Aida Leisenring and others) to schedule a call addressing these inmate condition issues.
